choices.text: It provides an alternative route for N2 excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid
It provides an alternative route for N2 excretion through the N-acetyl glucuronic acid conjugate kynurenine
It neutralized NH3 in both blood as well as urine

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby, with a family history of a urea cycle disorder leading to the death of a sibling at 1 year of age, has been diagnosed with the same condition. What is the rationale for administering benzoic acid to individuals with a urea cycle enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It provides an alternative route for N2 excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid

 

Option A:

                             

  • In urea cycle disorder, amino nitrogen is eliminated in other forms.
  • e.g., as hippuric acid (Benzoyl conjugate of glycine) or phenyl acetyl glutamine.
  • SODIUM BENZOATE (benzoic acid )+ Co A ðŸ¡ª Benzoyl co A + glycine (LIVER) ðŸ¡ª Benzoyl glycine (HIPPURIC ACID) ðŸ¡ª excreted in urine
  • 1 mole of Benzoic acid ðŸ¡ª removes ðŸ¡ª 1 mole of NH3 as glycine
  • SODIUM PHENYLACETATE  + Co A ðŸ¡ª SODIUM PHENYL ACETYL CoA + glutamine ðŸ¡ª SODIUM PHENYL ACETYL glutamine ðŸ¡ª urine
  • 1 mole of PHENYL ACETATE ðŸ¡ª removes ðŸ¡ª 2 moles of NH3 as glutamine

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It provides an alternative route for nitrogen (N2) excretion through the N-acetyl glucuronic acid conjugate kynurenine: This option is not accurate; kynurenine is a metabolite in the tryptophan degradation pathway and not directly related to the excretion of nitrogen in the context of urea cycle disorders.

 

Option C. It inhibits adenylate deaminase: Adenylate deaminase is not directly relevant to the management of urea cycle disorders or the mechanism of action of benzoic acid in these conditions.

 

Option D. It neutralizes ammonia (NH3) in both blood and urine: Benzoic acid does not neutralize ammonia directly; instead, it provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion by forming hippuric acid with glycine.

 

Educational Objective:

           

In urea cycle disorders, benzoic acid provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion by forming hippuric acid with glycine, thus reducing ammonia levels in the body. This is crucial for managing hyperammonemia resulting from the body's impaired ability to convert ammonia to urea.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: page 206.

choices.text: Bypassing carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II)

questions.text: A neonate is lethargic, drowsy, and irritable with blood analysis showing hyperammonemia and orotic aciduria. Considering this patient, orotic acid levels are high due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bypassing carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II)

 

Option C:

 

  • The rate limiting step for de novo pyrimidine synthesis is carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II), which produces carbamoyl phosphate in the cytoplasm.
  • In an OTC deficiency, the carbamoyl phosphate produced in the mitochondria leaks into the cytoplasm leading to orotic acid synthesis as the regulated step of the pathway is being bypassed.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, Option B. The elevated ammonia is not a substrate of CPS-II and which glutamine is also elevated and is a substrate of CPS-II, higher glutamine concentrations will not overcome enzyme inhibition by its allosteric inhibitor, UTP.

 

Option D. Aspartate transcarbamoylase is the regulated step of pyrimidine biosynthesis in many prokaryotic cells, but not in humans. This step is necessary for pyrimidines to be synthesized starting with carbamoyl phosphate.

 

Educational Objective:


Hyperammonemia and orotic aciduria in a neonate suggest a urea cycle defect, particularly ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, leading to the diversion of carbamoyl phosphate into the pyrimidine synthesis pathway and bypassing CPS-II.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy presents with lethargy and vomiting. His blood tests show high ammonia levels, and there's a family history of a similar condition in a male relative. Considering these findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ornithine transcarbamylase

 

Option B:

 

  • Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency is the only urea cycle disorder inherited as an X-linked trait.
  • Hyperammonemia Type II is due to OTC deficiency.
  • Mothers have hyperammonemia and an aversion to high protein diet.
  • Elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Carbamoyl-phosphate synthase I: Deficiency in this enzyme leads to a urea cycle disorder, but it is not specifically associated with hyperammonemia type 2.

 

Option C. Argininosuccinate synthetase: This enzyme deficiency leads to citrullinemia, another type of urea cycle disorder, but not hyperammonemia type 2.

 

Option D. Arginase: Arginase deficiency results in argininemia, yet another distinct urea cycle disorder, which also does not correspond to hyperammonemia type 2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperammonemia type 2 is specifically associated with a deficiency in the enzyme ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 206.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with CNS dysfunction including altered sensorium, convulsions, ascites, jaundice, and distinct tufted hair. Abdominal ultrasound reveals hepatomegaly, and laboratory tests show elevated ammonia and high argininosuccinate levels in the cerebrospinal fluid. Which enzyme deficiency is likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Argininosuccinate lyase.
 

Option A:

 

  • Argininosuccinic aciduria is due to the metabolic defect of Argininosuccinate lyase results in elevated levels of Argininosuccinate in blood, CSF, and urine.
  • A classic feature - friable, tufted hair (trichorrhexis nodosa) is also seen.
  • Diagnosis: measurement of erythrocyte Argininosuccinate lyase activity on umbilical cord blood or amniotic fluid cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B Arginase: Hyperargininemia - Arginine increased in blood and CSF. Instead of arginine, cysteine and lysine are lost in urine.

 

Option C. Argininosuccinate synthetase: Citrullinemia - with high blood levels of synthetase ammonia and citrulline and Citrullinuria.

 

Option D. Fumarase: Argininosuccinate is cleaved by argininosuccinate lyase (argininosuccinase) to arginine and fumarate. The enzyme is inhibited by fumarase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency is the cause of argininosuccinic aciduria, which is characterized by elevated levels of ammonia and argininosuccinate, leading to symptoms of CNS dysfunction and hepatomegaly.

 

Ref: Harper30/e: p 295, Vasudevan 9/e: P 205-206.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with episodic confusion, vomiting, and a history of protein-averse eating habits. Laboratory evaluations reveal elevated serum ammonia. Further genetic testing indicates a defect in the transport of a specific amino acid into the mitochondria. Which of the following deficiency corresponds with these clinical findings in the context of the hyperammonemia-hyperornithinemia-homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ornithine transporter deficiency

 

Option A:

 

Ornithine transporter deficiency is characterized by hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia and homocitrullinuria (HHH syndrome). 

 

Ornithine has to be transported into the mitochondria and citrulline has to come out since the urea cycle is compartmentalized.

 

Ornithine accumulates in the cytoplasm. Since ornithine is not available in the mitochondria, lysine is carbamoylated to form homocitrulline.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency causes Hyperammonemia type I. 

 

Option C. Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency causes Hyperammonemia Type II.

 

Option D. Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency is characterized by hyperammonemia and citrullinemia with elevated CSF citrulline levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HHH syndrome is characterized by a triad of hyperammonemia, hyperornithinemia, and homocitrullinuria, which arises from a defect in the mitochondrial ornithine transporter.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with episodic irritability, vomiting, and brittle hair with peculiar 'trichorrhexis nodosa' on microscopy. Blood work reveals elevated plasma ammonia and argininosuccinic acid levels. The child has a known deficiency in a urea cycle enzyme. To bypass the enzymatic block and reduce hyperammonemia, which supplement should be added to the child’s treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arginine

 

Option B:

 

  • Argininosuccinase (argininosuccinate lyase) catalyzes the cleavage of argininosuccinate into arginine and fumarate
  • Thus, in argininosuccinase deficiency arginine cannot be produced
  • Supplementation with arginine base helps replenish this amino acid

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspartate: While aspartate is a participant in the urea cycle, it is used earlier in the cycle and its supplementation does not bypass the block caused by argininosuccinase deficiency.

 

Option C. Citrulline: Citrulline is upstream of the block and would not be effective in bypassing the enzyme deficiency.

 

Option D. Argininosuccinate: This is the substrate that accumulates due to the enzyme deficiency and its supplementation would not be helpful.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argininosuccinic aciduria results from a deficiency in the enzyme argininosuccinase (argininosuccinate lyase), leading to an accumulation of argininosuccinic acid and hyperammonemia. Supplementation with arginine is beneficial as it provides an essential amino acid that is normally produced by the urea cycle and becomes essential in patients with this condition. This supplementation helps to continue the urea cycle, thus aiding in the detoxification of ammonia.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 204.

questions.text: A newborn becomes lethargic and drowsy on day 24 post-birth. Laboratory tests reveal hyperammonemia and orotic aciduria. Which compound is this infant unable to directly synthesize due to an enzymatic deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Citrulline

 

Option B:

 

  • The child has ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) deficiency and cannot condense carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to produce citrulline.
  • The excess carbamoyl phosphate leaks into the cytoplasm where it bypasses the regulated enzyme of de novo pyrimidine production, leading to excess orotic acid.
  • Thus, in an OTC defect, carbamoyl phosphate can be produced, but citrulline cannot.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Carbamoyl phosphate: This compound is actually synthesized in excess in OTC deficiency because it cannot be properly utilized to form citrulline.

 

Option C. Argininosuccinate: The formation of argininosuccinate occurs after the synthesis of citrulline in the urea cycle, so while its production is also affected, the direct deficiency lies with the production of citrulline.

 

Option D. Arginine: Arginine is the final product of the urea cycle, and its synthesis is indeed affected by OTC deficiency, but the immediate block is at the formation of citrulline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, is one of the urea cycle disorders. OTC is responsible for the synthesis of citrulline from carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine. When OTC is deficient, carbamoyl phosphate cannot be converted to citrulline and instead is diverted to the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, leading to orotic aciduria.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a diagnosed urea cycle disorder presents with recurrent episodes of hyperammonemia, especially after high-protein meals. Despite dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavenging medications, the child's ammonia levels remain intermittently elevated, leading to concerns about long-term neurological outcomes. The metabolic specialist considers augmenting the treatment regimen. Which combination of supplements could provide an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion and help manage the child's condition more effectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Arginine and benzoate

 

Option C:

 

  • For urea cycle defects, arginine becomes an essential amino acid (as its route of synthesis is the urea cycle).
  • Benzoate, along with phenylbutyrate, is given to patients with urea cycle defects to conjugate with a nitrogen carrying molecule (benzoate conjugated with glycine while phenylbutyrate, after activation to phenylacetate, conjugates with glutamine), which is then excreted.
  • The reactions of benzoate and phenylbutyrate with nitrogen containing amino acids takes place.
  • The excretion of glycyl-benzoate reduces the glycine levels of the body, forcing more glycine to be produced and providing an alternative pathway for nitrogen disposal in the absence of a functional urea cycle.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arginine and glutamine: Glutamine is often elevated in UCDs as it binds with free ammonia; however, supplementation with glutamine is not typically used for treatment because the body is already producing excess.

 

Option B. Lysine and glutamine: Lysine is not specifically involved in the urea cycle, and, as mentioned, glutamine is typically already elevated in UCDs.

 

Option D. Lysine and benzoate: Lysine is not a supplement used in the management of UCDs, and while benzoate is used, it would not be paired with lysine for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urea cycle disorders (UCDs) result in the body's inability to properly dispose of waste nitrogen from protein metabolism, leading to hyperammonemia. Arginine supplementation can be beneficial because it provides an essential amino acid that is often deficient in UCDs.

 

Benzoate combines with glycine to form hippurate, which provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion. This combination can help reduce ammonia levels in the blood by providing substrates for other nitrogen disposal pathways.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205

questions.text: The Nitrogen sources of UREA are ammonia and arginine. Choose the appropriate response.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False

 

Option B:

 

The two nitrogen atoms of urea are derived from two different sources, one from ammonia and the other from the alpha amino group of aspartic acid.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urea cycle uses nitrogen from ammonia and aspartate, with ammonia entering through carbamoyl phosphate and aspartate contributing through its conversion to argininosuccinate. Arginine, while an intermediate, is not a primary nitrogen source but is cleaved to produce urea.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 203.
